questions.question: The crow dropped the piece of cheese ………………………. the fox snapped up immediately.
questions.description: We use which to refer to things.

questions.question: People …………………....…. live in glass houses must not throw stones.
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses, both who and that can be used to refer to people.

questions.question: Last year we visited the Leaning Tower of Pisa …………………….. is a great architectural marvel.
questions.description: In non-identifying relative clauses, we cannot use that. A non-identifying relative clause merely provides additional information. It does not identify its antecedent.

questions.question: Where is the book ……………………… I left here yesterday?
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses, both which and that can be used to refer to things.

questions.question: It was a wretched hut ……………………….. she lived.
questions.description:
When we separate these two clauses, we get: it was a wretched hut she lived in it.
When we combine them we replace the prepositional phrase ‘in it’ with ‘in which’.

questions.question: Napoleon, ……………………… the French admire, was a great General.
questions.description: Napoleon was a great General. The French admire him. We need ‘whom’ to replace ‘him’.

questions.question: The boys gave a loud shout ………………………. was heard across the park.
questions.description: We use which to refer to things and ideas.

questions.question: The conference ………………….. was held at a Five Star hotel was a huge success.
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses, both which and that can be used to refer to things.

questions.question: The boy spoke to the soldier …………………….. arm was in a sling.
questions.description: When we separate the clauses, we get: the boy spoke to the soldier his arm was in a sling. To replace ‘his’ we use ‘whose’.

questions.question: The captain praised Martin, …………………. bowling was very good.
questions.description:
When we separate the clauses, we get:
The captain praised Martin.
His bowling was very good.
To replace ‘his’ we use ‘whose’.

questions.question: James, ……………………… is my cousin, is a pilot.
questions.description: In non-identifying relative clauses, we cannot use that. A non-identifying relative clause merely provides additional information. It does not identify the antecedent.

questions.question: That girl ……………………… you see there sings very well.
questions.description: The girl sings very well. You see her there. To replace 'her' we use 'whom'.
